text: ION
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: By Plato
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Translated by Benjamin Jowett
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: INTRODUCTION.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: The Ion is the shortest, or nearly the shortest, of all the writings
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: which bear the name of Plato, and is not authenticated by any early
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: external testimony. The grace and beauty of this little work supply the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: only, and perhaps a sufficient, proof of its genuineness. The plan is
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: simple; the dramatic interest consists entirely in the contrast
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: between the irony of Socrates and the transparent vanity and childlike
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: enthusiasm of the rhapsode Ion. The theme of the Dialogue may possibly
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: have been suggested by the passage of Xenophon's Memorabilia in which
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the rhapsodists are described by Euthydemus as 'very precise about the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: exact words of Homer, but very idiotic themselves.' (Compare Aristotle,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Met.)
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Ion the rhapsode has just come to Athens; he has been exhibiting in
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Epidaurus at the festival of Asclepius, and is intending to exhibit
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: at the festival of the Panathenaea. Socrates admires and envies the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: rhapsode's art; for he is always well dressed and in good company--in
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the company of good poets and of Homer, who is the prince of them. In
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the course of conversation the admission is elicited from Ion that his
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: skill is restricted to Homer, and that he knows nothing of inferior
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: poets, such as Hesiod and Archilochus;--he brightens up and is wide
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: awake when Homer is being recited, but is apt to go to sleep at the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: recitations of any other poet. 'And yet, surely, he who knows the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: superior ought to know the inferior also;--he who can judge of the good
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: speaker is able to judge of the bad. And poetry is a whole; and he
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: who judges of poetry by rules of art ought to be able to judge of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: all poetry.' This is confirmed by the analogy of sculpture, painting,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: flute-playing, and the other arts. The argument is at last brought home
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: to the mind of Ion, who asks how this contradiction is to be solved. The
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: solution given by Socrates is as follows:--
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: The rhapsode is not guided by rules of art, but is an inspired person
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: who derives a mysterious power from the poet; and the poet, in like
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: manner, is inspired by the God. The poets and their interpreters may be
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: compared to a chain of magnetic rings suspended from one another, and
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: from a magnet. The magnet is the Muse, and the ring which immediately
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: follows is the poet himself; from him are suspended other poets; there
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: is also a chain of rhapsodes and actors, who also hang from the Muses,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: but are let down at the side; and the last ring of all is the spectator.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: The poet is the inspired interpreter of the God, and this is the reason
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: why some poets, like Homer, are restricted to a single theme, or,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: like Tynnichus, are famous for a single poem; and the rhapsode is
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the inspired interpreter of the poet, and for a similar reason some
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: rhapsodes, like Ion, are the interpreters of single poets.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Ion is delighted at the notion of being inspired, and acknowledges that
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: he is beside himself when he is performing;--his eyes rain tears and his
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: hair stands on end. Socrates is of opinion that a man must be mad who
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: behaves in this way at a festival when he is surrounded by his friends
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: and there is nothing to trouble him. Ion is confident that Socrates
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: would never think him mad if he could only hear his embellishments
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: of Homer. Socrates asks whether he can speak well about everything
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: in Homer. 'Yes, indeed he can.' 'What about things of which he has no
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: knowledge?' Ion answers that he can interpret anything in Homer. But,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: rejoins Socrates, when Homer speaks of the arts, as for example, of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: chariot-driving, or of medicine, or of prophecy, or of navigation--will
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: he, or will the charioteer or physician or prophet or pilot be the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: better judge? Ion is compelled to admit that every man will judge of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: his own particular art better than the rhapsode. He still maintains,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: however, that he understands the art of the general as well as any one.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: 'Then why in this city of Athens, in which men of merit are always being
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: sought after, is he not at once appointed a general?' Ion replies that
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: he is a foreigner, and the Athenians and Spartans will not appoint a
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: foreigner to be their general. 'No, that is not the real reason; there
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: are many examples to the contrary. But Ion has long been playing tricks
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: with the argument; like Proteus, he transforms himself into a variety of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: shapes, and is at last about to run away in the disguise of a general.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Would he rather be regarded as inspired or dishonest?' Ion, who has no
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: suspicion of the irony of Socrates, eagerly embraces the alternative of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: inspiration.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: The Ion, like the other earlier Platonic Dialogues, is a mixture of jest
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: and earnest, in which no definite result is obtained, but some Socratic
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: or Platonic truths are allowed dimly to appear.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: The elements of a true theory of poetry are contained in the notion
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: that the poet is inspired. Genius is often said to be unconscious, or
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: spontaneous, or a gift of nature: that 'genius is akin to madness' is a
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: popular aphorism of modern times. The greatest strength is observed to
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: have an element of limitation. Sense or passion are too much for
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the 'dry light' of intelligence which mingles with them and becomes
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: discoloured by them. Imagination is often at war with reason and fact.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: The concentration of the mind on a single object, or on a single aspect
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: of human nature, overpowers the orderly perception of the whole. Yet the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: feelings too bring truths home to the minds of many who in the way of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: reason would be incapable of understanding them. Reflections of this
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: kind may have been passing before Plato's mind when he describes the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: poet as inspired, or when, as in the Apology, he speaks of poets as the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: worst critics of their own writings--anybody taken at random from the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: crowd is a better interpreter of them than they are of themselves. They
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: are sacred persons, 'winged and holy things' who have a touch of madness
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: in their composition (Phaedr.), and should be treated with every sort
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: of respect (Republic), but not allowed to live in a well-ordered state.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Like the Statesmen in the Meno, they have a divine instinct, but they
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: are narrow and confused; they do not attain to the clearness of ideas,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: or to the knowledge of poetry or of any other art as a whole.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: In the Protagoras the ancient poets are recognized by Protagoras himself
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: as the original sophists; and this family resemblance may be traced in
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the Ion. The rhapsode belongs to the realm of imitation and of opinion:
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: he professes to have all knowledge, which is derived by him from Homer,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: just as the sophist professes to have all wisdom, which is contained
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: in his art of rhetoric. Even more than the sophist he is incapable of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: appreciating the commonest logical distinctions; he cannot explain the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: nature of his own art; his great memory contrasts with his inability
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: to follow the steps of the argument. And in his highest moments of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: inspiration he has an eye to his own gains.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: The old quarrel between philosophy and poetry, which in the Republic
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: leads to their final separation, is already working in the mind of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Plato, and is embodied by him in the contrast between Socrates and Ion.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Yet here, as in the Republic, Socrates shows a sympathy with the poetic
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: nature. Also, the manner in which Ion is affected by his own recitations
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: affords a lively illustration of the power which, in the Republic,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Socrates attributes to dramatic performances over the mind of the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: performer. His allusion to his embellishments of Homer, in which
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: he declares himself to have surpassed Metrodorus of Lampsacus and
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Stesimbrotus of Thasos, seems to show that, like them, he belonged to
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the allegorical school of interpreters. The circumstance that nothing
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: more is known of him may be adduced in confirmation of the argument that
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: this truly Platonic little work is not a forgery of later times.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: PERSONS OF THE DIALOGUE: Socrates, Ion.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Welcome, Ion. Are you from your native city of Ephesus?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: No, Socrates; but from Epidaurus, where I attended the festival of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Asclepius.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And do the Epidaurians have contests of rhapsodes at the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: festival?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: O yes; and of all sorts of musical performers.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And were you one of the competitors--and did you succeed?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: I obtained the first prize of all, Socrates.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Well done; and I hope that you will do the same for us at the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Panathenaea.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: And I will, please heaven.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: I often envy the profession of a rhapsode, Ion; for you have
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: always to wear fine clothes, and to look as beautiful as you can is a
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: part of your art. Then, again, you are obliged to be continually in the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: company of many good poets; and especially of Homer, who is the best
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: and most divine of them; and to understand him, and not merely learn
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: his words by rote, is a thing greatly to be envied. And no man can be
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: a rhapsode who does not understand the meaning of the poet. For the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: rhapsode ought to interpret the mind of the poet to his hearers, but
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: how can he interpret him well unless he knows what he means? All this is
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: greatly to be envied.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Very true, Socrates; interpretation has certainly been the most
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: laborious part of my art; and I believe myself able to speak about
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Homer better than any man; and that neither Metrodorus of Lampsacus, nor
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Stesimbrotus of Thasos, nor Glaucon, nor any one else who ever was, had
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: as good ideas about Homer as I have, or as many.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: I am glad to hear you say so, Ion; I see that you will not
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: refuse to acquaint me with them.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Certainly, Socrates; and you really ought to hear how exquisitely I
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: render Homer. I think that the Homeridae should give me a golden crown.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: I shall take an opportunity of hearing your embellishments
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: of him at some other time. But just now I should like to ask you a
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: question: Does your art extend to Hesiod and Archilochus, or to Homer
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: only?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: To Homer only; he is in himself quite enough.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Are there any things about which Homer and Hesiod agree?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes; in my opinion there are a good many.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And can you interpret better what Homer says, or what Hesiod
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: says, about these matters in which they agree?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: I can interpret them equally well, Socrates, where they agree.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But what about matters in which they do not agree?--for
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: example, about divination, of which both Homer and Hesiod have something
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: to say,--
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Very true:
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Would you or a good prophet be a better interpreter of what
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: these two poets say about divination, not only when they agree, but when
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: they disagree?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: A prophet.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And if you were a prophet, would you not be able to interpret
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: them when they disagree as well as when they agree?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Clearly.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But how did you come to have this skill about Homer only, and
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: not about Hesiod or the other poets? Does not Homer speak of the same
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: themes which all other poets handle? Is not war his great argument? and
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: does he not speak of human society and of intercourse of men, good and
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: bad, skilled and unskilled, and of the gods conversing with one another
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: and with mankind, and about what happens in heaven and in the world
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: below, and the generations of gods and heroes? Are not these the themes
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: of which Homer sings?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Very true, Socrates.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And do not the other poets sing of the same?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes, Socrates; but not in the same way as Homer.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: What, in a worse way?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes, in a far worse.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And Homer in a better way?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: He is incomparably better.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And yet surely, my dear friend Ion, in a discussion about
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: arithmetic, where many people are speaking, and one speaks better than
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the rest, there is somebody who can judge which of them is the good
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: speaker?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And he who judges of the good will be the same as he who
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: judges of the bad speakers?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: The same.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And he will be the arithmetician?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Well, and in discussions about the wholesomeness of food, when
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: many persons are speaking, and one speaks better than the rest, will
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: he who recognizes the better speaker be a different person from him who
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: recognizes the worse, or the same?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Clearly the same.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And who is he, and what is his name?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: The physician.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And speaking generally, in all discussions in which the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: subject is the same and many men are speaking, will not he who knows the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: good know the bad speaker also? For if he does not know the bad, neither
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: will he know the good when the same topic is being discussed.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: True.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Is not the same person skilful in both?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And you say that Homer and the other poets, such as Hesiod and
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Archilochus, speak of the same things, although not in the same way; but
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the one speaks well and the other not so well?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes; and I am right in saying so.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And if you knew the good speaker, you would also know the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: inferior speakers to be inferior?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: That is true.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Then, my dear friend, can I be mistaken in saying that Ion
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: is equally skilled in Homer and in other poets, since he himself
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: acknowledges that the same person will be a good judge of all those who
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: speak of the same things; and that almost all poets do speak of the same
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: things?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Why then, Socrates, do I lose attention and go to sleep and have
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: absolutely no ideas of the least value, when any one speaks of any
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: other poet; but when Homer is mentioned, I wake up at once and am all
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: attention and have plenty to say?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: The reason, my friend, is obvious. No one can fail to see that
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: you speak of Homer without any art or knowledge. If you were able to
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: speak of him by rules of art, you would have been able to speak of all
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: other poets; for poetry is a whole.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And when any one acquires any other art as a whole, the same
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: may be said of them. Would you like me to explain my meaning, Ion?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes, indeed, Socrates; I very much wish that you would: for I love
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: to hear you wise men talk.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: O that we were wise, Ion, and that you could truly call us so;
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: but you rhapsodes and actors, and the poets whose verses you sing, are
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: wise; whereas I am a common man, who only speak the truth. For consider
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: what a very commonplace and trivial thing is this which I have said--a
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: thing which any man might say: that when a man has acquired a knowledge
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: of a whole art, the enquiry into good and bad is one and the same. Let
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: us consider this matter; is not the art of painting a whole?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And there are and have been many painters good and bad?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And did you ever know any one who was skilful in pointing
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: out the excellences and defects of Polygnotus the son of Aglaophon, but
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: incapable of criticizing other painters; and when the work of any other
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: painter was produced, went to sleep and was at a loss, and had no ideas;
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: but when he had to give his opinion about Polygnotus, or whoever the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: painter might be, and about him only, woke up and was attentive and had
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: plenty to say?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: No indeed, I have never known such a person.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Or did you ever know of any one in sculpture, who was skilful
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: in expounding the merits of Daedalus the son of Metion, or of Epeius
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the son of Panopeus, or of Theodorus the Samian, or of any individual
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: sculptor; but when the works of sculptors in general were produced, was
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: at a loss and went to sleep and had nothing to say?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: No indeed; no more than the other.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And if I am not mistaken, you never met with any one among
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: flute-players or harp-players or singers to the harp or rhapsodes who
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: was able to discourse of Olympus or Thamyras or Orpheus, or Phemius the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: rhapsode of Ithaca, but was at a loss when he came to speak of Ion of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Ephesus, and had no notion of his merits or defects?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: I cannot deny what you say, Socrates. Nevertheless I am conscious
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: in my own self, and the world agrees with me in thinking that I do speak
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: better and have more to say about Homer than any other man. But I do not
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: speak equally well about others--tell me the reason of this.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: I perceive, Ion; and I will proceed to explain to you what I
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: imagine to be the reason of this. The gift which you possess of speaking
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: excellently about Homer is not an art, but, as I was just saying, an
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: inspiration; there is a divinity moving you, like that contained in the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: stone which Euripides calls a magnet, but which is commonly known as
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the stone of Heraclea. This stone not only attracts iron rings, but also
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: imparts to them a similar power of attracting other rings; and sometimes
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: you may see a number of pieces of iron and rings suspended from one
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: another so as to form quite a long chain: and all of them derive their
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: power of suspension from the original stone. In like manner the Muse
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: first of all inspires men herself; and from these inspired persons a
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: chain of other persons is suspended, who take the inspiration. For all
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: good poets, epic as well as lyric, compose their beautiful poems not by
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: art, but because they are inspired and possessed. And as the Corybantian
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: revellers when they dance are not in their right mind, so the lyric
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: poets are not in their right mind when they are composing their
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: beautiful strains: but when falling under the power of music and metre
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: they are inspired and possessed; like Bacchic maidens who draw milk and
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: honey from the rivers when they are under the influence of Dionysus but
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: not when they are in their right mind. And the soul of the lyric poet
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: does the same, as they themselves say; for they tell us that they bring
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: songs from honeyed fountains, culling them out of the gardens and dells
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: of the Muses; they, like the bees, winging their way from flower to
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: flower. And this is true. For the poet is a light and winged and holy
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: thing, and there is no invention in him until he has been inspired and
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: is out of his senses, and the mind is no longer in him: when he has
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: not attained to this state, he is powerless and is unable to utter his
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: oracles. Many are the noble words in which poets speak concerning the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: actions of men; but like yourself when speaking about Homer, they do
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: not speak of them by any rules of art: they are simply inspired to utter
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: that to which the Muse impels them, and that only; and when inspired,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: one of them will make dithyrambs, another hymns of praise, another
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: choral strains, another epic or iambic verses--and he who is good at
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: one is not good at any other kind of verse: for not by art does the poet
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: sing, but by power divine. Had he learned by rules of art, he would have
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: known how to speak not of one theme only, but of all; and therefore God
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: takes away the minds of poets, and uses them as his ministers, as he
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: also uses diviners and holy prophets, in order that we who hear them
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: may know them to be speaking not of themselves who utter these priceless
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: words in a state of unconsciousness, but that God himself is the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: speaker, and that through them he is conversing with us. And Tynnichus
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the Chalcidian affords a striking instance of what I am saying: he wrote
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: nothing that any one would care to remember but the famous paean which
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: is in every one's mouth, one of the finest poems ever written, simply
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: an invention of the Muses, as he himself says. For in this way the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: God would seem to indicate to us and not allow us to doubt that these
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: beautiful poems are not human, or the work of man, but divine and the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: work of God; and that the poets are only the interpreters of the Gods by
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: whom they are severally possessed. Was not this the lesson which the God
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: intended to teach when by the mouth of the worst of poets he sang the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: best of songs? Am I not right, Ion?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes, indeed, Socrates, I feel that you are; for your words touch
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: my soul, and I am persuaded that good poets by a divine inspiration
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: interpret the things of the Gods to us.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And you rhapsodists are the interpreters of the poets?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: There again you are right.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Then you are the interpreters of interpreters?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Precisely.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: I wish you would frankly tell me, Ion, what I am going to ask
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: of you: When you produce the greatest effect upon the audience in the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: recitation of some striking passage, such as the apparition of Odysseus
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: leaping forth on the floor, recognized by the suitors and casting his
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: arrows at his feet, or the description of Achilles rushing at Hector,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: or the sorrows of Andromache, Hecuba, or Priam,--are you in your right
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: mind? Are you not carried out of yourself, and does not your soul in
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: an ecstasy seem to be among the persons or places of which you are
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: speaking, whether they are in Ithaca or in Troy or whatever may be the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: scene of the poem?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: That proof strikes home to me, Socrates. For I must frankly confess
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: that at the tale of pity my eyes are filled with tears, and when I speak
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: of horrors, my hair stands on end and my heart throbs.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Well, Ion, and what are we to say of a man who at a sacrifice
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: or festival, when he is dressed in holiday attire, and has golden
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: crowns upon his head, of which nobody has robbed him, appears weeping
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: or panic-stricken in the presence of more than twenty thousand friendly
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: faces, when there is no one despoiling or wronging him;--is he in his
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: right mind or is he not?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: No indeed, Socrates, I must say that, strictly speaking, he is not
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: in his right mind.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And are you aware that you produce similar effects on most of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the spectators?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Only too well; for I look down upon them from the stage, and behold
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the various emotions of pity, wonder, sternness, stamped upon their
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: countenances when I am speaking: and I am obliged to give my very best
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: attention to them; for if I make them cry I myself shall laugh, and if I
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: make them laugh I myself shall cry when the time of payment arrives.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Do you know that the spectator is the last of the rings
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: which, as I am saying, receive the power of the original magnet from
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: one another? The rhapsode like yourself and the actor are intermediate
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: links, and the poet himself is the first of them. Through all these the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: God sways the souls of men in any direction which he pleases, and makes
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: one man hang down from another. Thus there is a vast chain of dancers
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: and masters and under-masters of choruses, who are suspended, as if from
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the stone, at the side of the rings which hang down from the Muse. And
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: every poet has some Muse from whom he is suspended, and by whom he is
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: said to be possessed, which is nearly the same thing; for he is taken
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: hold of. And from these first rings, which are the poets, depend others,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: some deriving their inspiration from Orpheus, others from Musaeus; but
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the greater number are possessed and held by Homer. Of whom, Ion, you
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: are one, and are possessed by Homer; and when any one repeats the words
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: of another poet you go to sleep, and know not what to say; but when any
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: one recites a strain of Homer you wake up in a moment, and your
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: soul leaps within you, and you have plenty to say; for not by art or
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: knowledge about Homer do you say what you say, but by divine inspiration
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: and by possession; just as the Corybantian revellers too have a quick
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: perception of that strain only which is appropriated to the God by whom
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: they are possessed, and have plenty of dances and words for that, but
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: take no heed of any other. And you, Ion, when the name of Homer is
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: mentioned have plenty to say, and have nothing to say of others. You
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ask, 'Why is this?' The answer is that you praise Homer not by art but
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: by divine inspiration.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: That is good, Socrates; and yet I doubt whether you will ever have
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: eloquence enough to persuade me that I praise Homer only when I am mad
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: and possessed; and if you could hear me speak of him I am sure you would
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: never think this to be the case.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: I should like very much to hear you, but not until you have
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: answered a question which I have to ask. On what part of Homer do you
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: speak well?--not surely about every part.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: There is no part, Socrates, about which I do not speak well: of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: that I can assure you.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Surely not about things in Homer of which you have no
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: knowledge?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: And what is there in Homer of which I have no knowledge?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Why, does not Homer speak in many passages about arts? For
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: example, about driving; if I can only remember the lines I will repeat
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: them.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: I remember, and will repeat them.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Tell me then, what Nestor says to Antilochus, his son,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: where he bids him be careful of the turn at the horserace in honour of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Patroclus.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: 'Bend gently,' he says, 'in the polished chariot to the left of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: them, and urge the horse on the right hand with whip and voice; and
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: slacken the rein. And when you are at the goal, let the left horse draw
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: near, yet so that the nave of the well-wrought wheel may not even seem
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: to touch the extremity; and avoid catching the stone (Il.).'
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Enough. Now, Ion, will the charioteer or the physician be the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: better judge of the propriety of these lines?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: The charioteer, clearly.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And will the reason be that this is his art, or will there be
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: any other reason?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: No, that will be the reason.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And every art is appointed by God to have knowledge of a
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: certain work; for that which we know by the art of the pilot we do not
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: know by the art of medicine?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Certainly not.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Nor do we know by the art of the carpenter that which we know
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: by the art of medicine?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Certainly not.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And this is true of all the arts;--that which we know with one
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: art we do not know with the other? But let me ask a prior question: You
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: admit that there are differences of arts?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: You would argue, as I should, that when one art is of one kind
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: of knowledge and another of another, they are different?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Yes, surely; for if the subject of knowledge were the same,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: there would be no meaning in saying that the arts were different,--if
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: they both gave the same knowledge. For example, I know that here are
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: five fingers, and you know the same. And if I were to ask whether I
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: and you became acquainted with this fact by the help of the same art of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: arithmetic, you would acknowledge that we did?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Tell me, then, what I was intending to ask you,--whether this
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: holds universally? Must the same art have the same subject of knowledge,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: and different arts other subjects of knowledge?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: That is my opinion, Socrates.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Then he who has no knowledge of a particular art will have no
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: right judgment of the sayings and doings of that art?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Very true.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Then which will be a better judge of the lines which you were
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: reciting from Homer, you or the charioteer?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: The charioteer.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Why, yes, because you are a rhapsode and not a charioteer.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And the art of the rhapsode is different from that of the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: charioteer?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And if a different knowledge, then a knowledge of different
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: matters?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: True.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: You know the passage in which Hecamede, the concubine of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Nestor, is described as giving to the wounded Machaon a posset, as he
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: says,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: 'Made with Pramnian wine; and she grated cheese of goat's milk with a
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: grater of bronze, and at his side placed an onion which gives a relish
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: to drink (Il.).'
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Now would you say that the art of the rhapsode or the art of medicine
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: was better able to judge of the propriety of these lines?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: The art of medicine.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And when Homer says,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: 'And she descended into the deep like a leaden plummet, which, set in
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the horn of ox that ranges in the fields, rushes along carrying death
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: among the ravenous fishes (Il.),'--
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: will the art of the fisherman or of the rhapsode be better able to judge
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: whether these lines are rightly expressed or not?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Clearly, Socrates, the art of the fisherman.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Come now, suppose that you were to say to me: 'Since you,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Socrates, are able to assign different passages in Homer to their
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: corresponding arts, I wish that you would tell me what are the passages
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: of which the excellence ought to be judged by the prophet and prophetic
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: art'; and you will see how readily and truly I shall answer you. For
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: there are many such passages, particularly in the Odyssee; as, for
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: example, the passage in which Theoclymenus the prophet of the house of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Melampus says to the suitors:--
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: 'Wretched men! what is happening to you? Your heads and your faces
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: and your limbs underneath are shrouded in night; and the voice of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: lamentation bursts forth, and your cheeks are wet with tears. And the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: vestibule is full, and the court is full, of ghosts descending into the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: darkness of Erebus, and the sun has perished out of heaven, and an evil
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: mist is spread abroad (Od.).'
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: And there are many such passages in the Iliad also; as for example in
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the description of the battle near the rampart, where he says:--
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: 'As they were eager to pass the ditch, there came to them an omen: a
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: soaring eagle, holding back the people on the left, bore a huge bloody
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: dragon in his talons, still living and panting; nor had he yet resigned
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the strife, for he bent back and smote the bird which carried him on the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: breast by the neck, and he in pain let him fall from him to the ground
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: into the midst of the multitude. And the eagle, with a cry, was borne
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: afar on the wings of the wind (Il.).'
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: These are the sort of things which I should say that the prophet ought
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: to consider and determine.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: And you are quite right, Socrates, in saying so.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Yes, Ion, and you are right also. And as I have selected from
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the Iliad and Odyssee for you passages which describe the office of the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: prophet and the physician and the fisherman, do you, who know Homer so
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: much better than I do, Ion, select for me passages which relate to the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: rhapsode and the rhapsode's art, and which the rhapsode ought to examine
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: and judge of better than other men.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: All passages, I should say, Socrates.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Not all, Ion, surely. Have you already forgotten what you were
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: saying? A rhapsode ought to have a better memory.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Why, what am I forgetting?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Do you not remember that you declared the art of the rhapsode
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: to be different from the art of the charioteer?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes, I remember.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And you admitted that being different they would have
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: different subjects of knowledge?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Then upon your own showing the rhapsode, and the art of the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: rhapsode, will not know everything?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: I should exclude certain things, Socrates.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: You mean to say that you would exclude pretty much the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: subjects of the other arts. As he does not know all of them, which of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: them will he know?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: He will know what a man and what a woman ought to say, and what
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: a freeman and what a slave ought to say, and what a ruler and what a
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: subject.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Do you mean that a rhapsode will know better than the pilot
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: what the ruler of a sea-tossed vessel ought to say?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: No; the pilot will know best.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Or will the rhapsode know better than the physician what the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ruler of a sick man ought to say?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: He will not.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But he will know what a slave ought to say?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Suppose the slave to be a cowherd; the rhapsode will know
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: better than the cowherd what he ought to say in order to soothe the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: infuriated cows?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: No, he will not.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But he will know what a spinning-woman ought to say about the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: working of wool?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: No.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: At any rate he will know what a general ought to say when
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: exhorting his soldiers?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes, that is the sort of thing which the rhapsode will be sure to
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: know.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Well, but is the art of the rhapsode the art of the general?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: I am sure that I should know what a general ought to say.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Why, yes, Ion, because you may possibly have a knowledge of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the art of the general as well as of the rhapsode; and you may also have
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: a knowledge of horsemanship as well as of the lyre: and then you would
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: know when horses were well or ill managed. But suppose I were to ask
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: you: By the help of which art, Ion, do you know whether horses are well
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: managed, by your skill as a horseman or as a performer on the lyre--what
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: would you answer?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: I should reply, by my skill as a horseman.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And if you judged of performers on the lyre, you would
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: admit that you judged of them as a performer on the lyre, and not as a
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: horseman?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And in judging of the general's art, do you judge of it as a
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: general or a rhapsode?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: To me there appears to be no difference between them.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: What do you mean? Do you mean to say that the art of the
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: rhapsode and of the general is the same?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Yes, one and the same.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Then he who is a good rhapsode is also a good general?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Certainly, Socrates.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And he who is a good general is also a good rhapsode?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: No; I do not say that.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But you do say that he who is a good rhapsode is also a good
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: general.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Certainly.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And you are the best of Hellenic rhapsodes?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Far the best, Socrates.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: And are you the best general, Ion?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: To be sure, Socrates; and Homer was my master.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: But then, Ion, what in the name of goodness can be the reason
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: why you, who are the best of generals as well as the best of rhapsodes
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: in all Hellas, go about as a rhapsode when you might be a general? Do
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: you think that the Hellenes want a rhapsode with his golden crown, and
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: do not want a general?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Why, Socrates, the reason is, that my countrymen, the Ephesians,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: are the servants and soldiers of Athens, and do not need a general; and
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: you and Sparta are not likely to have me, for you think that you have
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: enough generals of your own.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: My good Ion, did you never hear of Apollodorus of Cyzicus?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: Who may he be?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: One who, though a foreigner, has often been chosen their
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: general by the Athenians: and there is Phanosthenes of Andros, and
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: Heraclides of Clazomenae, whom they have also appointed to the command
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: of their armies and to other offices, although aliens, after they had
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: shown their merit. And will they not choose Ion the Ephesian to be
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: their general, and honour him, if he prove himself worthy? Were not
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: the Ephesians originally Athenians, and Ephesus is no mean city? But,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: indeed, Ion, if you are correct in saying that by art and knowledge you
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: are able to praise Homer, you do not deal fairly with me, and after
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: all your professions of knowing many glorious things about Homer, and
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: promises that you would exhibit them, you are only a deceiver, and so
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: far from exhibiting the art of which you are a master, will not, even
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: after my repeated entreaties, explain to me the nature of it. You have
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: literally as many forms as Proteus; and now you go all manner of ways,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: twisting and turning, and, like Proteus, become all manner of people
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: at once, and at last slip away from me in the disguise of a general, in
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: order that you may escape exhibiting your Homeric lore. And if you have
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: art, then, as I was saying, in falsifying your promise that you would
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: exhibit Homer, you are not dealing fairly with me. But if, as I believe,
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: you have no art, but speak all these beautiful words about Homer
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: unconsciously under his inspiring influence, then I acquit you of
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: dishonesty, and shall only say that you are inspired. Which do you
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: prefer to be thought, dishonest or inspired?
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: ION: There is a great difference, Socrates, between the two
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: alternatives; and inspiration is by far the nobler.
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: SOCRATES: Then, Ion, I shall assume the nobler alternative; and
title: Ion
author: Plato

text: attribute to you in your praises of Homer inspiration, and not art.
title: Ion
author: Plato
